div1.head: Newspaper clipping, October 8, [1926]
div1.p:
Birthplace of “Father of Pub-
lic Health Work” to Be
Dedicated Saturday.

NEWPORT NEWS, Va., October 8.
--Belroi, the birthplace of Dr. Wal-
ter Reed, the founder of public health
work, will be dedicated at 2 o'clock
next Saturday afternoon in Gloucester
County.

Dr. E. C. S. Taliaferro of Norfolk
will preside at the exercises. A de-
votional will be conducted by Rev.
O. L. Haga of the Glouscester cir-
cuit, Methodist Episcopal Church
South. Dr. Clarence Porter Jones of
Newport News will give a history of
the Walter Reed Memorial and Dr.
Lawrence P. Royster, president of the
Virginia Medical Society, will speak
on the value of Reed's pioneering to
medical research.

Mrs. William Fleet Taliaferro,
Schuyler Otis Bland, Col. Randolph
Jefferson Kean of Walter Reed Hos-
pital, Washington, will give addresses.

Benediction will be said by Rev.
James C. Reed, brother of Dr. Walter
Reed, who was active in ministerial
work of the Virginia Conference of
the Methodist Church for 53 years.

Belroi will be preserved as a me-
morial. Built 100 to 150 years ago,
this little building has an interesting
history, but Dr. Reed made it his-
torically important.

Credit for restoring Belroi belongs
to the Walter Reed Memorial Com-
mission, created by the Medical So-
ciety of Virginia in 1926. The work
of restoration was done during July
and August, 1927, at a cost of $2,500.
The entire building was raised with
jacks and the foundation pillars
strengthened. The flooring was re-
placed and the large chimney, which
had been removed, was built into its
original place with the same bricks.
The clapboards in front only are old,
original, and the new roof is of riven
cypress shingles.

The house contains only three
rooms, the front portion being only
a story and a half, with a small wind-
ing stairway in one corner to the
“guest's room” with a small window
above. The rear room, which is the
newer portion--a kind of lean-to addi-
tion--is the one in which Walter
Reed was born. The external dimen-
sions of the quaint little house are
21 feet long and 24 feet wide. A
log building that once stood in the
rear will be restored. It was 10 by
12 feet in size, and was used as a
kitchen. The memorial commission
will eventually, when funds justify,
inclose the entire property with a
suitable fence.
Belroi, the home where Dr. Walter Reed was born in Gloucester County, Va.
